item.title: New model for superconductivity
item.description:
New model for superconductivity:

https://physics.aps.org/articles/v16/s170

"The researchers found that the order parameter in each
case is determined by the effective repulsion energy
between two electrons located at the same atomic site in
the crystal divided by the electron kinetic energy. This
suggests that materials exhibiting stronger
electron-electron repulsion should sustain larger
superconducting currents and have higher Tc's. It also
supports a particular mechanism for electron pairing that
leads to superconductivity -a counterintuitive concept
known as attraction by repulsion."

item.title: Disable SharePlay on iOS
item.description:
Disable SharePlay on iOS:

1. Goto Setting->FaceTime

2. Turn off "SharePlay"

From: https://osxdaily.com/2023/11/28/how-to-turn-off-shareplay-on-iphone/

item.description:
Disable NameDrop on iOS 17:

1. Goto Settings->Generally->AirDrop

2. Turn off "Bringing Devices Together"

From: https://www.ghacks.net/2023/11/27/iphone-namedrop-warning-mdp/

item.title: Bacteria may be one of the causes of itching
item.description:
Bacteria may be one of the causes of itching:

https://www.statnews.com/2023/11/22/mystery-scratch-itch-staphylococcus-aureus-bacterium/

"[R]esearch showed that when [the bacteria] S. aureus
invades the skin, it releases 10 different enzymes, or
proteases. One of them, called V8, latches on to a protein
on nerve cells called proteinase-activated receptor 1, or
PAR1. The scientists said they believe this starts a chain
reaction from the skin neurons, to the spinal cord, and to
the brain, which then triggers the urge to itch."

item.title: The myth and reality of Snow Leopard (MacOSX 10.6.x)
item.description:
The myth and reality of Snow Leopard (MacOSX 10.6.x):

https://lapcatsoftware.com/articles/2023/11/5.html

Some of the fond recollections for Snow Leopard are probably
also due Lion (MacOSX 10.7.x) dropping Rosetta.

Tiger (MacOSX 10.4.x) is also probably remembered fondly
because it was the last version to include Classic.

item.title: Dinky's "moon" is actual a two bodies
item.description:
Dinky's "moon" is actual a two bodies:

https://www.livescience.com/space/asteroids/newfound-moon-around-asteroid-dinkinesh-is-actually-two-tiny-moons-touching

"On its first asteroid flyby on Nov. 1, NASA's Lucy
mission discovered that the main belt asteroid Dinkinesh
has a small moon orbiting it. Now, additional images have
revealed another surprise: Dinkinesh's moon is not one,
but two small satellites. The twin moons initially
appeared as one because they are so close together, they
touch as they orbit."

item.title: Shortcut for extra low brightness on iOS
item.description:
Shortcut for extra low brightness on iOS:

https://practicalbetterments.com/create-a-shortcut-for-even-lower-phone-brightness/

Settings->Accessibility->Accessibility shortcut->Reduce White Point

"I wish all manufacturers did this."

item.title: Starfish are mostly head
item.description:
Starfish are mostly head:

https://www.cnn.com/2023/11/02/world/starfish-head-body-plan-scn/index.html

"[N]ew genetic research suggests ... that sea stars are
largely heads that lack torsos or tails and likely lost
those features evolutionarily over time.  The researchers
said the bizarre fossils of sea star ancestors, which
appeared to have a kind of torso, make a lot more sense in
evolutionary terms in light of the new findings.

...

 'When we compared the expression of genes in a starfish
 to other groups of animals, like vertebrates, it appeared
 that a crucial part of the body plan was missing,' [one
 of the researchers] said. 'The genes that are typically
 involved in the patterning of the trunk of the animal
 weren't expressed in the ectoderm. It seems the whole
 echinoderm body plan is roughly equivalent to the head in
 other groups of animals.'"

item.title: N-9?
item.description:
N-9?:

https://physics.aps.org/articles/v16/186
https://www.sciencenews.org/article/physicists-elusive-isotope-nitrogen-9

"With seven protons and two neutrons, the lopsided atomic
nucleus of nitrogen-9 pushes the limits of what can even
be considered a nucleus at all.

...

Protons and neutrons, the subatomic particles that make up
atomic nuclei, are essentially glued together by the
strong nuclear force ...[, b]ut the force can't
hold together nuclei that have wildly skewed ratios of
protons to neutrons. Too many of either particle -
especially protons, which repel each other due to their
positive charge - and the nuclear bucket starts to
overflow.

Beyond this overflow point, which physicists call the
'drip line,' nuclei cannot fully bind their particles.

...

Finding a nucleus as far beyond the drip line as
nitrogen-9 - five protons beyond - was surprising ...
[because, u]ntil now, scientists had only ever found
isotopes up to four protons beyond the drip line."
